issue.title: Destroy operations do not seem to be idempotent
issue.body:
If the namespace doesn't exist, I would expect the destroy operation to be fully idempotent and carry on. The current behavior fails with ` namespaces "monitoring" not found`

### Terraform Version, Provider Version and Kubernetes Version
<!--- Run `terraform -v` to show the version. If you are not running the latest version of Terraform, please upgrade because your issue may have already been fixed. --->
```
Terraform version: v1.2.5
Kubernetes provider version: 2.13.1
Kubernetes version: 1.21 (EKS)
```

### References
* https://hashicorp.github.io/terraform-provider-aws/running-and-writing-acceptance-tests/#disappears-acceptance-tests

### Community Note
<!--- Please keep this note for the community --->
* Please vote on this issue by adding a 👍 [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to the original issue to help the community and maintainers prioritize this request
* If you are interested in working on this issue or have submitted a pull request, please leave a comment

comment.body: FWIW, this is potentially also caused by lack of idempotency in the provider: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1455. My team ran into it today.

commits.message: Update README to account for new API

Fix error reporting for reader

since it was never making out of the local scope.

payload.description: Go package to natively decompress and unarchive tar.gz, tar.bzip2, tar.xz, zip and tar files.

commits.message:
Simplify API

To reduce confusion regarding destination path passed as argument
versus returned, and prevent accidental misuse. The destination
path is now always required.

issue.title: Destroy operations are not idempotent

labels.name: waiting-response
labels.description: An issue/pull request is waiting for a response from the community

labels.name: waiting for reproduction
labels.description: unable to reproduce issue without further information

issue.body:
### Terraform Version

```shell
v1.2.8
```


### Terraform Configuration Files

any resource or data source from at least the kubernetes or AWS provider. 

### Debug Output

...

### Expected Behavior

Destroy operations should be idempotent for data sources and resources alike. Otherwise, they are non-deterministic altogether. I started noticing the issue with some providers such as with data sources in the AWS providers and regular resources with the Kubernetes providers. After thinking for a while and reporting the issues on the specific providers' repos, I decided to raise it up in core because this pattern seems to be prevalent and the Terraform Plugin SDK nor the Terraform Framework SDK seem to encourage or facilitate testing for idempotent destroy operations. 

### Actual Behavior

destroy operations fail when remote resources do not exist. See: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1822 and https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/26228 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. terraform init
2. terraform apply 
3. manually delete remote resource either through AWS Console/CLI/API or GCP Console/CLI/API.
4. terraform destroy

### Additional Context

_No response_

### References

* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/26228
* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1822
* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/pull/27408

comment.body:
@bflad won me to it 🥇. 
 
@jbardin, thanks for such a prompt answer. I also was leaning towards kicking this ball to the providers but then I thought that this issue really effects the Terraform brand because the user experience ends up being inconsistent. It would be ideal if Terraform core somehow helps providers to be fully idempotent, either by making it easier or possible for providers to test idempotent destroy operations. Agreed with @bflad on that maybe the best venue for this discussion is the plugin framework SDK.

issue.body:
### Terraform Version

```shell
v1.2.8
```


### Terraform Configuration Files

any resource or data source from at least the kubernetes or AWS provider. 

### Debug Output

...

### Expected Behavior

Destroy operations should be idempotent for data sources and resources alike. Otherwise, they are non-deterministic altogether. I started noticing the issue with some providers such as with data sources in the AWS providers and regular resources with the Kubernetes providers. After thinking for a while and reporting the issues on the specific providers' repos, I decided to raise it up in core because this pattern seems to be prevalent and the Terraform Plugin SDK nor the Terraform Framework SDK seem to encourage or facilitate testing for idempotent destroy operations. 

### Actual Behavior

destroy operations fail when remote resources do not exist. See: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1822 and https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/26228 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. terraform init
2. terraform apply 
3. manually delete remote resource either through AWS Console/CLI or GCP Console/CLI.
4. terraform destroy

### Additional Context

_No response_

### References

* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/26228
* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1822
* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/pull/27408

issue.title: context: clarify guidance on whether a canceled context can cause a graceful termination vs. immediate termination

labels.name: NeedsInvestigation
labels.description: Someone must examine and confirm this is a valid issue and not a duplicate of an existing one.

issue.body:
Since `context.Context` has been introduced, I've understood it such that a canceled context should cause an _immediate_ return from a function. I see this same expectation in almost all source code I read, stdlib and otherwise. Some exceptions exist -- I think some of the `go mod` code has a hardcoded 1s upper bound for some graceful termination -- but this can be seen as _relatively_ immediate.

In the context docs, the main line that hints at an immediate return is `A CancelFunc tells an operation to abandon its work`. However, nothing in the context documentation actually discusses how quickly a cancelation should be reacted to, nor in the linked context blog post, nor in that post's linked pipelines post.

I've seen a few times where a canceled context is used to _begin_ a graceful shutdown, which itself could take 30s. I've restructured this existing code to instead have a separate "BeginShutdown" method and switch any usage of contexts to immediate-return semantics. But, there remains confusion on why we shouldn't use contexts in the graceful shutdown way. At the end of the day, my recommendation usually boils down to

* The whole ecosystem is programmed around relatively immediate returns when a context is canceled
* If people assume context cancelation _begins_ a shutdown, this removes the possibility of causing a forceful shutdown

This isn't really great nor official guidance, though.

This issue is also a bit more important in the context of `signal.NotifyContext`, which I've seen people use to begin a graceful shutdown of their applications (rather than an immediate shutdown), and in `exec.CommandContext`, where people are surprised by the underlying Kill rather than Interrupt.

Is it possible to clarify whether a canceled context should cause immediate returns? Or, is it fine to begin a long graceful shutdown?

comment.body: I agree with @twmb's feedback regarding the official guidance being rather loose. If the expectation and idiomatic approach is an immediate cancellation, as it can be seem throughout the standard library, I guess the only thing to do here is to make that more explicit in the documentation.

issue.title: Potential race condition between groups and group membership when using SCIM app.
issue.body: We have been consistently hitting a race condition when we create group and assign it membership, for groups that are being pushed to AWS SSO through the SCIM app. The error we get in Okta is the following: To work around it, we have been doing the following: 1. Remove group membership 1. terraform apply 1. Manually push the group again from Okta's Web UI to AWS SSO 1. Add group membership back again 1. terraform apply

comment.body: @monde, no, very small, 4 or 3 users.

issue.title: aws_s3_object data source fails on destroy with a 404 if object does not exist

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Addresses a defect in current functionality.

labels.name: service/s3
labels.description: Issues and PRs that pertain to the s3 service.

issue.body: This happens during `terraform destroy`, when Terraform is refreshing the state. The expected behavior is for the `terraform destroy` operation to be idempotent by having the providers ignore read errors since the object is already deleted or missing.

comment.body: This may have been introduced here: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/pull/27408

issue.title: aws_s3_object data source fails on destroy with a 404 if object does not exist

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Addresses a defect in current functionality.

labels.name: service/s3
labels.description: Issues and PRs that pertain to the s3 service.

issue.body: This happens during `terraform destroy`, when Terraform is refreshing the state. The expected behavior is for the `terraform destroy` operation to be idempotent by having the providers ignore read errors since the object is already deleted or missing.

comment.body: @teddylear, I'm not aware of data source resources that work like that to be honest. I only know that their current behavior break idempotency of destroy operations.

issue.title: aws_s3_object data source fails on destroy with a 404 if object does not exist

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Addresses a defect in current functionality.

labels.name: service/s3
labels.description: Issues and PRs that pertain to the s3 service.

issue.body: This happens during `terraform destroy`, when Terraform is refreshing the state. The expected behavior is for the `terraform destroy` operation to be idempotent by having the providers ignore read errors since the object is already deleted or missing.

comment.body: On apply, it should throw an error. It should only ignore 404s or don’t read the source on destroy.

issue.title: aws_s3_object data source fails on destroy with a 404 if object does not exist

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Addresses a defect in current functionality.

labels.name: service/s3
labels.description: Issues and PRs that pertain to the s3 service.

issue.body: It should instead behave idempotently by ignoring the error since the object is already deleted.

comment.body: @teddylear, during `terraform destroy` operations, terraform refreshes state and that's when data sources fail, literally any data source missing its remote objects will fail. I verified the GCP provider and their object datasource will also fail.

issue.title: Destroy operations do not seem to be idempotent
issue.body:
If the namespace doesn't exist, I would expect the destroy operation to be fully idempotent and carry on. The current behavior fails with ` namespaces "monitoring" not found`

### Terraform Version, Provider Version and Kubernetes Version
<!--- Run `terraform -v` to show the version. If you are not running the latest version of Terraform, please upgrade because your issue may have already been fixed. --->
```
Terraform version: v1.2.5
Kubernetes provider version: 2.13.1
Kubernetes version: 1.21 (EKS)
```

### References
* https://hashicorp.github.io/terraform-provider-aws/running-and-writing-acceptance-tests/#disappears-acceptance-tests

### Community Note
<!--- Please keep this note for the community --->
* Please vote on this issue by adding a 👍 [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to the original issue to help the community and maintainers prioritize this request
* If you are interested in working on this issue or have submitted a pull request, please leave a comment

comment.body: FWIW, this is potentially also caused by lack of idempotency in the provider: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1455. My team ran into it today.

commits.message: Update README to account for new API

Fix error reporting for reader

since it was never making out of the local scope.

payload.description: Go package to natively decompress and unarchive tar.gz, tar.bzip2, tar.xz, zip and tar files.

commits.message:
Simplify API

To reduce confusion regarding destination path passed as argument
versus returned, and prevent accidental misuse. The destination
path is now always required.

issue.title: Destroy operations are not idempotent

labels.name: waiting-response
labels.description: An issue/pull request is waiting for a response from the community

labels.name: waiting for reproduction
labels.description: unable to reproduce issue without further information

issue.body:
### Terraform Version

```shell
v1.2.8
```


### Terraform Configuration Files

any resource or data source from at least the kubernetes or AWS provider. 

### Debug Output

...

### Expected Behavior

Destroy operations should be idempotent for data sources and resources alike. Otherwise, they are non-deterministic altogether. I started noticing the issue with some providers such as with data sources in the AWS providers and regular resources with the Kubernetes providers. After thinking for a while and reporting the issues on the specific providers' repos, I decided to raise it up in core because this pattern seems to be prevalent and the Terraform Plugin SDK nor the Terraform Framework SDK seem to encourage or facilitate testing for idempotent destroy operations. 

### Actual Behavior

destroy operations fail when remote resources do not exist. See: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1822 and https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/26228 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. terraform init
2. terraform apply 
3. manually delete remote resource either through AWS Console/CLI/API or GCP Console/CLI/API.
4. terraform destroy

### Additional Context

_No response_

### References

* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/26228
* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1822
* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/pull/27408

comment.body:
@bflad won me to it 🥇. 
 
@jbardin, thanks for such a prompt answer. I also was leaning towards kicking this ball to the providers but then I thought that this issue really effects the Terraform brand because the user experience ends up being inconsistent. It would be ideal if Terraform core somehow helps providers to be fully idempotent, either by making it easier or possible for providers to test idempotent destroy operations. Agreed with @bflad on that maybe the best venue for this discussion is the plugin framework SDK.

issue.title: context: clarify guidance on whether a canceled context can cause a graceful termination vs. immediate termination

labels.name: NeedsInvestigation
labels.description: Someone must examine and confirm this is a valid issue and not a duplicate of an existing one.

issue.body:
Since `context.Context` has been introduced, I've understood it such that a canceled context should cause an _immediate_ return from a function. I see this same expectation in almost all source code I read, stdlib and otherwise. Some exceptions exist -- I think some of the `go mod` code has a hardcoded 1s upper bound for some graceful termination -- but this can be seen as _relatively_ immediate.

In the context docs, the main line that hints at an immediate return is `A CancelFunc tells an operation to abandon its work`. However, nothing in the context documentation actually discusses how quickly a cancelation should be reacted to, nor in the linked context blog post, nor in that post's linked pipelines post.

I've seen a few times where a canceled context is used to _begin_ a graceful shutdown, which itself could take 30s. I've restructured this existing code to instead have a separate "BeginShutdown" method and switch any usage of contexts to immediate-return semantics. But, there remains confusion on why we shouldn't use contexts in the graceful shutdown way. At the end of the day, my recommendation usually boils down to

* The whole ecosystem is programmed around relatively immediate returns when a context is canceled
* If people assume context cancelation _begins_ a shutdown, this removes the possibility of causing a forceful shutdown

This isn't really great nor official guidance, though.

This issue is also a bit more important in the context of `signal.NotifyContext`, which I've seen people use to begin a graceful shutdown of their applications (rather than an immediate shutdown), and in `exec.CommandContext`, where people are surprised by the underlying Kill rather than Interrupt.

Is it possible to clarify whether a canceled context should cause immediate returns? Or, is it fine to begin a long graceful shutdown?

comment.body: I agree with @twmb's feedback regarding the official guidance being rather loose. If the expectation and idiomatic approach is an immediate cancellation, as it can be seem throughout the standard library, I guess the only thing to do here is to make that more explicit in the documentation.

issue.title: Potential race condition between groups and group membership when using SCIM app.
issue.body: We have been consistently hitting a race condition when we create group and assign it membership, for groups that are being pushed to AWS SSO through the SCIM app. The error we get in Okta is the following: To work around it, we have been doing the following: 1. Remove group membership 1. terraform apply 1. Manually push the group again from Okta's Web UI to AWS SSO 1. Add group membership back again 1. terraform apply

comment.body: @monde, no, very small, 4 or 3 users.

issue.title: aws_s3_object data source fails on destroy with a 404 if object does not exist

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Addresses a defect in current functionality.

labels.name: service/s3
labels.description: Issues and PRs that pertain to the s3 service.

issue.body: This happens during `terraform destroy`, when Terraform is refreshing the state. The expected behavior is for the `terraform destroy` operation to be idempotent by having the providers ignore read errors since the object is already deleted or missing.

comment.body: This may have been introduced here: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/pull/27408
